With this S/ 1200.00 loan that she will return in 6 months, she will finish the construction of the floor of her business, and she will also buy chicken, potatoes on bulk, vegetables for salads, and other items that will attract the attention of her clients with high quality and higienic products.

Celinda is a 41-year-old perseverant and very friendly woman, that lives with her husband and two children, who help her to go on and reach her goals. For the future she wishes to improve and expand the environment of her business and improve service to her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Veronica MR, Kiva volunteer

La Señora Celinda García J. es socia del Banco Comunal “Unidad Calzadina”, vive en la Región San Martín y Provincia de Moyobamba y distrito de Calzada, su pollería se ubica en un ambiente construido especialmente para esta actividad, a la que diariamente asiste moradores de la comunidad a saborear los ricos pollo a la brasa que prepara. Se inicio en el negocio de la venta de abarrotes, pero su actitud visionaria le llevó a concretar este negocio de pollos a la braza que era muy solicitado en la comunidad en la que vive. Con el crédito de S/.1200.00 que devolverá en un plazo de pago de 6 meses, lo invertirá en el acabado del piso de su establecimiento, también comprará: pollos en javas, papas en sacos, verduras diversas para las ensaladas y otros que harán posible la buena atención a sus clientes con productos de buena calidad e higiénicos. Celinda es una mujer perseverante y muy amigable, tiene 41 años, vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos, quienes la impulsan a esforzarse cada día más y alcanzar sus objetivos, desea para el futuro mejorar y ampliar el ambiente donde desarrolla su negocio y así dar una mejor atención a sus clientes.

loans.use: With the loan she will buy raw products to prepare the products she sells

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Tran Thi N., 43 years old, joined the TYM Fund since 2006. Her family has 4 members: 2 parents and 2 children. At first, she used the borrowed money to buy mussels and sold them to the restaurants. Because she lives near the river, her business went very well. Every month, she profitted 130 USD. During these recent years, she borrows more money to buy iron and alluminum to make metal goods. Her business is going well, and during busy times, she has to hire more workers. Her average annual income is 2500 USD. She hopes to borrow more money to expand her business. This time, she wants to borrow 625 USD to buy iron and alluminum to make general carriers.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Trần Thị Ngọ, 43 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 2006. Gia đình chị gồm 2 vợ chồng và 2 con. Thời gian đầu chị Ngọ vay vốn thu mua hến cung cấp cho các nhà hàng. Sống gần sông nên việc thu mua hến rất thuận lợi. Mỗi tháng chị cũng lãi được khoảng 130USD. Vài năm gần đây, chị vay những mức vốn lớn mua sắt nhôm làm cơ khí. Công việc thuận lợi, vào những thời điểm đông khách, chị Ngọ phải thuê từ 2 đến 3 nhân công cùng làm. Hàng năm tổng thu nhập của gia đình đạt 2500USD. Mong muốn của chị là được vay những mức vốn lớn để mở rộng kinh doanh. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 625USD mua sắt, nhôm chế tạo xe thô sơ dùng chở vật liệu.

loans.use: Buy iron, aluminium

loans.name: Preap

texts.en: Preap P., 20, is married to Nut Meatie and lives in Siem Reap Province. He works at a coffee shop that provides him with a daily income of $3, while his wife is a teacher at church, making about $4 each day. Preap P. has an entrepreneurial mindset and believes that there is a good business opportunity in his area. He has approached CREDIT for a loan of $400 to combine with his personal savings to purchase a computer with which he hopes to transfer music onto cell phones. Cell phones are everywhere, especially in the urban areas, and transferring music to them is very popular. He wants to capitalize on this current trend and add to his daily income.

loans.use: To purchase a computer.

loans.name: Issowe Bernard

texts.fr:
Mr. Issowe Benard S. was born on October 14, 1970 in Lome. He is married and the father of three children. He is a retailer of electronic goods. His store, ETS AUREOLE WINBA, is located in the Adidogome district of Lome. He makes his cellphones and television monitors widely available by providing his customers with an attractive repayment plan, allowing them to purchase items through weekly payments.

His first business loan has been completely repaid. He is requesting this second loan to enable him to purchase eight (8) high quality cellphones and six (6) television monitors

Translated from French by Dave Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

Monsieur S. Issowe Bernard est né le 14 octobre 1970 à Lomé. Il est marié et père de trois enfants. Il est revendeur des appareils électroniques dans son magasin ETS AUREOLE WINBA dans le quartier Adidogomé à Lomé. Pour pouvoir permettre à tout le monde de disposer de portables et de télévision, il met à la disposition de ses clients un système de paiement relativement avantageux qui leur permet de d’acquérir des portables et de payer par semaine. Il a une fois bénéficié du crédit et a bien remboursé. Ce second crédit qu’il sollicite lui permettra d’acheter 8 téléphones portables de haute qualité et 6 postes téléviseurs.

loans.use: Purchase of Televisions and Cellphones

loans.name: Mrs. Soam Mach Group

texts.en: Mrs. Soam M. is the leader of this four member group in Phum Thom Village in Kandal Province. She is a cake maker and seller who earns a small income to support her family. Since her business is doing well, Mrs. Soam M. wants to make more cakes, so she has decided to ask for a loan to buy more ingredients to make cakes to sell door-to-door. Her husband, Mr. Eb Pheng, is a construction worker. Mrs. Soam M. is 48 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the one is a construction worker. The remaining two attend school.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients to make cakes to sell door-to-door.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La Señora Juana, socia del Banco Comunal “Micaela Bastidas”, vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui. Desde hace 6 años se dedica al diseño de modas y a la costura. El taller está ubicado en el Jr Mariscal Cáceres Nº 663, lugar donde acuden los clientes, porque es muy solicitada en la confección de todo tipo de prendas de vestir, tanto por su responsabilidad, puntualidad y como también por el buen acabado que le da a sus trabajos. 

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,200, el cual cancelará en 4 meses, comprará hilos de diferentes colores, telas de diversos colores y calidades, moldes, agujas y repuestos para su máquina. Además desea tener en stock todo lo necesario para atender sus pedidos. También trabaja con algunas instituciones en la confección  de uniformes.
 
Juana tiene 45 años, es separada, tiene 3 hijos a quienes quiere darles un futuro mejor y además son la razón de lucha cada día. Su meta es implementar su taller con máquinas, remalladora, maniquíes entre otras cosas, y de esa manera dar trabajo a personas que lo requieran.
texts.en:
Ms. Juana S., a member of the “Micaela Bastidas” microfinance institute, lives in the San Martín region of the Mariscal Cáceres province, in the Juanjui district. Ever since the age of six, she has been involved in fashion design and dressmaking. Her sewing workshop is located on Jr Mariscal Cáceres Nº 663, where her customers frequent because of her skills in making all kinds of apparel, her dependability, her punctuality, and her high quality finished products.

With this loan of 1,200.00 PEN, which she will repay in 4 months, she will purchase different color thread, various types and colors of fabric, sewing patterns, needles, and spare parts for her sewing machine. Additionally, she would like to have everything she needs in stock so that she can fill her orders. She also works with schools in order to make uniforms.

Juana is 45 years of age, separated, and has 3 children whom she wishes to give a better future; they are the reason why she struggles hard everyday. Her goal is to expand her workshop with more sewing machines, overlock machines, and mannequins, among other things, thus allowing her to offer employment to whoever may need it.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase thread, fabric, sewing patterns, needles, and spare parts for sewing her machine

loans.name: Rahmani's Group

texts.en:
Rahmani Baji is the wife of M. I. and lives in a small area named Riwind o Kasur, Pakistan. It is a half hour from Kasur. Riwind is an area full of fruits and vegetable markets. Rahmani Baji is married for the last 30 years. She is the mother of five sons. All of her sons run their own barber saloon. They have been in this business for the last 10 years. Rahmani Baji's husband makes car seat covers and sells them in the market. He has been in this business for the last 22 years. Rahmani Baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy chairs, a mirror and tools for her sons' barber saloon.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Jamila Baji wants a loan to buy more seasonal fruits to resell. Parveen Baji and Khursheed Baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material (chairs, mirrors) for barber saloon

loans.name: Adiza

texts.fr: Mlle B. Adiza est née en 1984 à Agoè-Zongo. Très tôt, elle entre en apprentissage de coiffure afin de mieux subvenir à ses besoins. Vu que la seule activité ne l’avantage pas, elle associe à cette dernière la vente des produits de beauté. Ce qui lui réussi bien. Mais devant ses maigres moyens, elle n’arrive pas à satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. Elle sollicite un financement pour s’acheter des produits de beauté et augmenter son étalage aussi pour  aménager son salon de coiffure.
texts.en:
Miss Adiza B. was born in 1984 in Agoè-Zongo. Very early in life, she joins a hairstyling apprenticeship in order to better provide for her needs. Since this activity alone does not benefit her, she also sells beauty products as part of the business. This has brought her success. However, due to a lack of means, she does not manage to satisfy her customers' requests. She is thus asking for financing to buy beauty products, to grow her display, and also to arrange her hairdressing salon.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy beauty products, grow window display and arrange hairdressing salon

loans.name: Samai

texts.en:
Mrs. Samai B., 29, and her husband, Mr. Van Veng, 25, who live on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 2002 and have two children; one son and one daughter. All of them attend school. 

Mrs. Samai has been a silk weaver nearly ten years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a wooden house builder for three years. Samai is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase silk material for weaving, to set up one more loom for her sister to weave silk, and to expand her husband’s business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving and to set up one more loom for her sister.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Susana L., 60, is married with 8 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the villagers and general public 2 days per week. She has had 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (about $145 USD).  SPBD loans are Susana’s only access to capital because she does not qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Her husband is a good carpenter and he earns money to help support the business and family.

loans.use: Purchase Gromoxone, sting, chemicals, bush knives and seedlings for her farm.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi ont en moyenne  37 ans et 4 enfants. Toutes mariées, ils vivent  en majorité dans des familles polygamiques au quartier Bamanan Kin Kirango de Markala Préfecture de Ségou(quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles se sont connues depuis à bas âge, ont grandi ensemble, sont restées unies même après leurs mariages dans le même quartier. Elles sont toutes membres de l’association  traditionnelle dénommée Faïda. Elles ont connu Soro Yiriwaso à travers l’assemblée générale des artisans de la commune de Markala au cours de laquelle toutes les associations féminines ont été conviées. 
Après avoir bien remboursé les prêts précédents, le groupe est à son 4ème prêt qui  sera utilisé pour acheter, 1 sac de concombre, 2 cartons de banane plantain, 1 sac d’orange, ½ sac de citron, 1sac de racines du doum > et 6 cartons de savon. Ces produits sont achetés une fois par semaine à la foire de Diamarabougou. A côté de ceux-ci elles font le petit commerce de haricot, de condiments alimentaires, des jarres et des canaris confectionnés à Kounkobougou et livrés à domicile spécialement aux revendeuses à Kirango. Ces produits sont vendus au comptant et à crédit  à  une clientèle composée  de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 22 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt,  payer les tontines et l’habillement des enfants. Elles ont pour ambition  d’avoir une maison d’habitation
texts.en:
The women of the Benkadi group have an average age of 37 years and on average, 4 children. All are married and most live in polygamous families in the Bamanan Kin Kirango neighborhood of Markala, prefecture of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They have known each other since they were children, grew up together, and remained close even after their marriages, in the same neighborhood. They are all members of a traditional association called Faïda. They learned about Soro Yiriwaso from the general assembly of artisans of the Markala community, during which all the women's associations convene.

After having reimbursed their preceding loans, the group is on their 4th loan which will be used to buy 1 sack of cucumbers, 2 cases of plantains, 1 sack of oranges, 1/2 sack of lemons, 1 sack of roots of doum palms, and 6 cases of soap. These products are bought once a week at the market fair of Diamarabougou. Besides these items, they sell beans, condiments, and jars and storage pots made in Kounkobougou and specially delivered to the homes of saleswomen in Kirango.

These products are sold for cash and on credit to a clientele composed of women and men. They expect to make an average profit of 22,000 F CFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan, save money in traditional associations, and dress their children. Their ambition is to have a house to live in.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy various items for re-sale

loans.name: Khon

texts.en:
Mr. Khon S. is a villager in Krang Chhoer Neang village in Takeo province. He is a 38-year-old father of four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school. The youngest one is too young to work or study. 

Mr. Khon S. is a cow breeder. Since his business is doing well, he wants to expand it by purchasing more cows for breeding so he can earn more income. 

His wife, Mrs. Touy Srey, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she grows rice.  His wife is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more cows for breeding

loans.name: Frida Ceferina

texts.es:
La señorita Frida Ceferina C. A. es socia del Banco Comunal “Corazones unidos”, en el distrito de Desaguadero, Provincia de Chucuito, Departamento de Puno; tiene 24 años de edad, de estado civil soltera, no tiene hijos y posee estudios de secundaria completa 
Ella Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 02 años, ella inició posee un negocio de venta de ropa al por menor (casacas, chompas, pantalones, etc.), su primer préstamo fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, con lo que pudo adquirir mercadería para su negocio.  
Sin embargo su negocio no le brindo muchas ganancias por lo que decidió cambiar de rubro y dedicarse a la venta de frutas y verduras, donde si pudo obtener buenas ganancias, actualmente desea mejorar este negocio por ello viene solicitando un préstamo adicional de S/. 1800.00 Nuevos soles, el mismo que se comprometa a pagar en 04 cuotas, con dicho préstamo desea adquirir mas mercaderías, es decir frutas según la temporada y verduras al por mayor  para poder venderlos en las ferias de Desaguadero y otras zonas. El futuro ella piensa colocar un bazar propio donde pueda tener productos de diferentes marcas comerciales (ropa al por mayor) que en cantidad da buenas ganancias.
texts.en:
Frida Ceferina C. A. is a member of Corazones Unidos Communal Banc, in the district of Desaguadero, province Chucuito, department Puno,in Peru; she is 24 years old, and has completed secondary studies. She is single, and has no children. She has been working with Movimiento Manuela Ramos for 02 years, and started to have her own clothing retail business (jackets, sweaters, pants, etc.). Her first loan was for S/. 300.00, which enabled her to buy merchandise for her business. However, her business did not do very well, and she decided to try a different type of business. Now she sells fruits and vegetables, and is doing very well. She would like to improve her business, so she is requesting a loan of S/. 1800.00, which she will repay in 04 installments. With the loan, she hopes to purchase merchandise -- seasonal fruits and whole sale vegetables to sell at the Desaguadero street market and markets in other districts. She hopes to one day have her own store where she can sell all different brands of clothing in whole sale, since selling good-sized amounts is profitable.

Translated from Spanish by Hannah Lily, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing seasonal fruits

loans.name: Bonanza Group

texts.es:
Este comité se formo a travéz de la Sra. Silvia G., a quien le gusto el programa, decidio invitar a sus vecinas y amigas del Asentamiento Bonanza para trabajar juntas y poder progresar. Ellas estan acostumbradas a organizarse por lo cual su grupo prospera. Ellas son independientes en sus labores como vendedoras de ropas, venta de comidas, venta de frutas, venta de joyas, Peluquera, etc. y reciben de crédito en un promedio de Gs. 433.000 cada una, quienes invierten en compra de azúcar, carne, harina,huevo , baquero, remeras,polleras,camisas,joyas, biyouteri, lenceria, bebidas gaseosas, verduras, escoba, champu, tinte.

1	Juliana G.	        Venta de comida
2	Marta P.	        Despensa
3	Laura M.	        Venta de Ropa

24	Griselda Fleitas	Venta de ropa
texts.en:
This committee was formed through Mrs. Silvia G. who, on liking the programme, decided to invite her neighbours and friends from the Bonanza Settlement to work together and make progress. They are used to being organised so their group is successful. They work independently selling clothes, food, fruit, jewellery, as a hairdresser, etc. They receive a loan that is on average Gs. 433,000 each which they will invest in the purchase of sugar, meat, flour, eggs, jeans, t-shirts, skirts, blouses, jewellery, lingerie, fizzy drinks, vegetables, brooms, shampoo and hair dye.

1 Juliana G. – food seller

2 Marta P. – sells groceries

3 Laura M. – clothes seller

4 Ramona M. – clothes seller

21 Norma V. – clothes seller

22 Ada G. - hairdresser

23 Bella R. – jewellery seller

24 Griselda Fleitas – clothes seller


Translated from Spanish by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar, meat, flour, eggs, jeans, t-shirts, blouses, jewellery, lingerie, fizzy drinks, vegetables, brooms, shampoo and hair dye

loans.name: Ameyo

texts.fr: Cette dame a appris la couture et a ouvert son propre atelier, elle a associé à son activité le commerce de pagnes, elle veut agrandir son stock de pagnes pour réaliser plus de recettes. elle sollicite donc de WAGES son premier crédit qui lui permettra d’acheter 8 pagnes  de  qualité PHOENIX, 8 pagnes de qualité HITARGET et 10 gripures. Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier de hedrzanawoé qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé. Avec cette activité elle contribue aux dépenses du foyer.
texts.en:
This is a woman who learned how to sew and opened her own workshop. She has included with it commerce in pagnes (colorful West African cloth). She wants to expand her stock of pagnes to realize more receipts. She's therefore requesting her first loan from WAGES that will enable her to buy eight PHOENIX quality pagnes, 8 HITARGET quality pagnes, and 10 guipures. She is married, the mother of three, and lives with her family in Hedrzanawoé, an outlying district of the city of Lomé. With this business, she helps to cover household expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pagne cloth

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en: Mrs. Angelita S. is struggling on her own to feed a sickly husband and two dependents of her seven children. Even though she is a woman, she performs like a man, climbing coconut trees to produce native wine for the benefit of the family. She is a hardworking, 55-year-old, married woman. Angelita has been an active member of Paglaum MPC for several years and has used previous loans to support her economic activity. She is now requesting a loan of 14,000 PHP for housing repairs and the purchase of electrical lights for her household. This is the current inspiration of her life.

loans.use: For housing repair and installation of electric light

loans.name: Philo

texts.en:
Philo sells foodstuffs like garri, made from cassava tubers. 

She is 25 years old and married with three children. 

She hopes for a loan of N100,000 (US$700) to purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Nargis Muhammad Yaqoob Group

texts.en:
Shabana baji wants a loan to buy vehicle wheels to sell.

Yasmeen baji wants a loan to buy mobile phones to sell.

Allah rakhi baji wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business.

Another Allah rakhi baji wants a loan to buy a welding machine.

Nargis baji is the group leader of these aforementioned ladies. They all belong to a city named Lahore, Pakistan, which is famous for its historical places and for its Punjabi foods. They all are very responsible ladies. Nargis baji is very happy to keep them in her group because of their good nature and behavior.

Nargis baji operates a clothes-sewing business because, in Pakistan, for parents to afford their children’s education expenses, they learn some skills; and sewing clothes is one of them. Nargis baji uses her income as needed.

Nargis baji’s husband is M. Y. who runs a game shop in the community. Kids come to his shop to play games. The snooker game is especially popular with children. She is applying for a loan to buy another snooker table for her husband’s game shop.

loans.use: To buy another snooker table for her husband's game shop

loans.name: Abdukarim

texts.ru: Данияров Абдукарим проживает в районе Рудаки. Возраст 60 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Абдукарим по специальности является врачом. По специальности, он работал около 35 лет. В данный момент, он более 10 лет занимается перевозкой. Он в основном перевозит животных. Клиент просит кредит, для ремонта машины.
texts.en:
Abdurakim D. lives in the Rudaki region. He is 60 years old. He is married and has six children. Abdurakim is a doctor by profession and has worked for around 35 years. At this time he has been in the transport business for more than ten years. He mainly transports animals. The client is asking for a loan to repair his vehicle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair a truck

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace E. sells peppers in retail to her customers. She is 38 years old and married with 7 children. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 Nigerian naira (or about $550 US) to purchase more peppers to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more peppers to sell

loans.name: Nazila

texts.en:
Nazila (her husband is pictured) is the mother of four children. She was born in 1970. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Azerbaijan Khankendy town. She is now settled in Baku city.

Her husband has been in the taxi business for ten years. Now Nazila needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy spare parts for her husband's taxi business.

loans.use: to buy the spare parts

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys is thirty seven year old woman. She is divorced and has two children, one in junior high school and the other just completed senior high and is waiting to enter the university. She is a food vendor and sells banku. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains cooked and taken with hot pepper or soup. She has many customers since it is enjoyed by many customers as breakfast, lunch and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more ingredients like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to raise increased income to support her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy raw materials.

loans.name: Bernarda

texts.en: Bernarda A. is from the village of Panduma Sr., Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 56 years old, is married, and has six school-aged children. Bernarda owns and operates a business selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Bernarda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Development Association Group

texts.en:
This is Adamsay S., Kadiatu C., Adamsay J., Dankay S. and Gbassay T.. They named their group Development Association. They are local entrepreneurs in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of Le 500,000 for each for the first time from Kiva Lenders through SMT. With the help of this loan, they will be able to improve their businesses, make more profit and consequently improving their standard of living.

 Adamsay S. is the leader of this group. Adamsay is age twenty-three; she was born in Magburaka town. Adamsay is single. She sells creams and ready-to-wear-clothes for women. She has been in this business for two years now.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Mario Eduardo

texts.pt:
Mário Eduardo de Benjamim L., natural de Tete, província de Tete, tem 39 anos de idade, casado e pai de 02 filhos com 07 e 01 anos de idade, o primeiro vai a escola. Fez o nível médio no ensino técnico profissional, parou de estudar porque não conseguiu ingressar no ensino superior. Vive na casa própria e não sustenta mais ninguém para alem da esposa e dos filhos.

Em 2002 saiu de Tete para Maputo junto com a sua família quando foi transferido pelos serviços. É funcionário público e faz 08 horas diárias, foi formado pela CIDOC (Instituto Médio de Ciências Documentais – Fundo bibliográfico da língua portuguesa) a 07 anos, aufere um salário mensal de 15.365,92mt com o qual sustenta a família e consegue poupar para melhorar a sua habitação.

Conheceu a Hluvuku através de colegas que são clientes da mesma, já trabalhou com o banco Barclays, não se recorda do valor mas foi para construção. 

Com o empréstimo de 15.000,00mt pretende comprar areia, pedra e cimento para concluir a sua obra. Compromete-se a pagar bem para poder aceder a novos empréstimos para mobilar a sua casa.
texts.en:
Mário Eduardo de Benjamim L. is from the Tete province. He is 39 years old, married and father of two children. His children are 7 and 1 years old, and the first one goes to school. Mário did high school at a professional school, but stopped his studies because he could not enter university. He lives in his own house and does not economically support anyone else beyond his wife and his two children. In 2002, he left Tete to Maputo with his family when he was transferred at this job. He works for government and does 08 hours/day. He graduated at CIDOC (High Institute of Sciences - Bibliographic Fund of Portuguese Language) 07 years ago. His monthly salary is 15,365.92 MZN with which he supports his family and saves to improve his house., He learnt about Hluvuku through his friends who are Hluvuku’s clients. He has worked with the bank Barclays. He doesn’t remember the value but it was used for construction. With the 15,000 MZN loan he intends to buy sand, stone, and cement in order to conclude his construction. He pledges to pay back well so that to have access to new loans in order to furnish his house.

Translated from Portuguese by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials (cement, sand and others)

loans.name: Lucresia

texts.en:
Lucresia B. is from the village of San Vicente. She is 49 years-old and married with four children. Two of them are adults and the other two are in school. Lucresia owns and operates a food stall. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks in the seaport of Dapitan City. Lucresia has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Lucresia joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucresia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. Lucresia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Lucresia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and provide working capital.

loans.name: Bolivia Group

texts.es:
El Banco comunal Bolivia está formado por 10 clientes, pertenecen a la Zona D. Pampahasi Central, que están ubicados alrededor D. la Institución Emprender, las socias se dedican a la venta D. Comida, Víveres, pan, Cerveza, Abarrotes, Confección D. polleras, venta D. pescado , venta D. ropa, Durante su permanencia en Emprender, que son 9 ciclos se reestructuro en un 40% D. las socias
Maria Corina  es la líder y presidenta del banco, es una D. las fundadoras del banco, teniendo en cuenta que el banco ya tiene como antigüedad 9 ciclos, la socia se dedica a la confección D. polleras. Durante su permanencia, en el banco comunal ha aprendido a ser una líder responsable con sus compañeras, exigente con sus cuotas D. sus compañeras a la hora D. pago, amigable, alegre, respetuosa con sus compañeras; con el préstamo que se le ha otorgado a podido aumentar su capital en su taller D. esta manera aumentar sus ingresos  familiares.
Yolandae es  la Tesorera del Banco es una D. las fundadoras que dio origen a la conformación del banco Bolivia se dedica a la venta D. pescado, en ferias, no contaba con capital para su actividad económica, sin embargo ahora con el préstamo que se le dará  ella podrá comprar  mas mercadería y así aumentar su capital y su estabilidad económica.
Nadia Erika  Socia nueva que se integra a la banca bastante dinámica, alegre, es la secretaria del Banco, actualmente la señora tiene una tienda D. barrio, el crédito lo invertirá en el aumento D. capital D. su tienda, como también comprara materia prima para la confección D. polleras
texts.en:
The communal Bolivian bank is maD. up of 10 clients who are from the Central Pampahasi zone, that are part of the Emprender Institution. The members work in the sale of food, provisions, bread, beer, groceries, shawls, fish, and clothing. During her tenure in Emprender, which has lasted for 9 cycles, there was a 40% restructuring of the bank’s membership. Maria Corina has been the head and president of the bank, and one of its founders. She works making shawls. During the time she has been in the communal bank she has learned how to be a responsible leader with the others. She is strict with their payments when the time comes, friendly, cheerful and respectful of them. With the loan she has been able to increase the capital in her shop to improve the family income. Yolanda is the bank’s treasurer and one of the bank’s founders. She sells fish at markets. She didn’t have any capital at the beginning but she is now asking for a loan so that she can buy more merchandise and thus increase her capital and her economic stability. Nadia Erika is a new member who has joined the bank. She is a dynamic and friendly person, and is the bank’s secretary. Currently this lady has a neighborhood store. She will invest the money to increase the store’s capital as well as to buy the supplies to make the shawls.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase capital

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic D. is from the village of Baylao, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 48 years old and married with eight school-aged children. To make a living, Marivic owns and operates a business selling wood and wood-related products in the local community. Marivic has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $133 a month from these activities.

In 2008, Marivic joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Marivic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. She is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en:
Ngozi sells stock fish (fish dried in the sun) at retail prices to her customers. Stock fish is used in the preparation of Nigerian soup like melon soup. She sells for long hours to enable her meet the basic needs of her family.

Ngozi is 48 years old and is married with six children. Her husband is a trader and he also supports the home.

Ngozi is a LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

The demand for Ngozi’s stock fish is high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more stock fish to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more stock fish to sell

loans.name: Idowu

texts.en:
Idowu is 54 years old, married and has five children. He lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. He is a LAPO client who makes a living selling plastic and building materials. Idowu loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He is requesting a loan for NGN 60,000 to buy more plastic items to sell. He extends his sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.   

LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To buy more plastics to sell

loans.name: Ligia

texts.en:
Ligia is a 45-year-old woman from La Unión, Cartago, located near the central valley of Costa Rica. She lives with her husband; they have no children together.

Although she did not finish high school, Ligia has managed to open a profitable sewing business and employs six young women (her nieces). She and her nieces make and sell sports clothing, casual clothing, children’s clothing and pajamas. The women work forty-eight hours a week on average.

Ligia started her business with an initial investment of 75,000 colons fourteen years ago. In a good month, her business can earn 2,000,000 colons; in a bad month only 1,200,000.

Ligia’s main client is a store that contracts Ligia’s business to produce clothing, which is then sold in the store. Her main obstacle in life as well as in business is her health. As a diabetic, she has many migraines and these have prevented her from effectively performing the duties of regular jobs. Ligia has created her own business so she can work in an environment that is flexible to her needs as a diabetic woman.

Ligia hopes she will continue to generate enough income from her business so that she won’t have to look for work elsewhere. Her goal is for her business to grow. She intends to use this loan to seek out new clients and to offer a more diverse range of products such as handmade blouses and vests. Her long term goal is to own a clothing store or boutique in order to sell clothes she has designed herself.

With this loan, Ligia will buy the raw materials necessary for her sewing business such as spools of thread, cloth, and sewing machines. The loan will also be used to hire more women to help her increase the output of her business. In this way she is not only providing work for herself and members of her family, but also for members of the community.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her sewing business and to hire more women

loans.name: Cindy Annabel

texts.es:
El banco comunal Confraternidad de Damas se reúnen en la ciudad de Portoviejo cada 15 días,  es un grupo  muy unido, conversamos con la señora Cindy para que nos cuente como le va trabajando con la Fundación.
                                                          
Cindy está casada desde hace seis  años, ella es comerciante informal que se dedica a vender ropa para damas, caballeros y niños, con este negocio viene trabajando desde hace un año,  empezó en el negocio con la ayuda de un préstamo que le hizo una amiga en aquel tiempo su capital fue de $400 dólares con eso invirtió y desde entonces le ha ido muy bien; ella pudo seguir surtiendo su negocio  y ahora con la ayuda que le brinda la fundación compra de contado la mercaderia obteniendo  mejores ganancias. 

Nuestra socia está muy contenta con su trabajo, cuenta que tiene que viajar hasta la ciudad de Guayaquil cada dos semana para surtir el negocio y cumplir con los pedidos que sus clientes le hacen, lo que invierte depende de los pedidos y la recuperación de capital una vez que ha reunido el dinero viaja para abastecerse de  mercaderia directa de los distribuidores. 

Por ahora Cindy tiene en mente invertir una parte del dinero en surtir y ampliar el local para  brindarle mejor comodidad a sus clientes adquiriendo pantalones, blusas, camisetas, bermudas así como tostadoras, wafleras, licuadoras e ir incrementando mas  electrodomésticos y accesorios para el hogar.

 El sueño de Cindy es poder tener su vivienda propia ya que al  momento vive en casa de su mamá.
texts.en:
The communal bank, "Confraternidad de Damas," meets in the city of Portoviejo every two weeks. It is a very united group. We spoke with Cindy so she could tell us about how it's going working with Fundación Espoir. Cindy has been married for six years. She is an informal merchant who sells clothing for women, men, and children. She has had this business for one year. She started it with the help of a loan that a friend made her for $400. She invested it in her business and since then it has gone very well. She has been able to to keep supplying her business and now with the help that Fundación Espoir is offering her, she will buy more merchandise with cash so she can obtain better profits. Our member is very happy with her work. She says that she has to travel to the city of Guayaquil every two weeks to be able to supply her business and to fill the orders that her customers aks for. What she invests depends on her orders, and after she has collected the money, she travels to buy merchandise directly from distributors. Now Cindy plans to invest part of the money in stocking and expanding her location to offer more comfort to her customers that shop for pants, shirts, t-shirts, shorts, and also toasters, waffle irons, and blenders. She will increase her inventory of household appliances and accessories for the home. Cindy's dream is to be able to have her own home since at the moment she lives in her mother's house.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pants, shirts, t-shirts, shorts, waffle irons, toasters, blenders, etc.

loans.name: Rebeka

texts.en:
Rebeka is 48 years old, married with 5 children who are 11, 18, 20, 21 and 25 years old.  Rebeka also takes care of two dependents who are 12 and 14 years old.  Rebeka and her family live in the Ngoma, a region of Rwamagana situated in the eastern province of Rwanda.  Here, Rebeka sells a variety of drinks.  This is her 15th successful year in this business and the hours of her business are from morning until late in the evening.

Rebeka is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through adding more drinks for sale.  With these additional drinks, Rebeka hopes to earn more profits, which in turn will allow her to reinvest in her business so that her business can keep growing.  If her plan is successful, Rebeka with the sustainability of her business, she will create some other sources of income as well as creating more jobs to the people of her community.

loans.use: Additional drinks for sale

loans.name: Roberto Carlos

texts.es: El Sr. Roberto Carlos es originario del municipio de El Sauce, su negocio consiste en brindar servicio de traslado a los pobladores de dicho municipio por medio de un tricitaxi donde tiene dos años de tener su negocio. Ha tenido tres créditos con Ceprodel los que le han beneficiado, ya que gracias a este capital ha podido adquirir estos bienes para trabajar por cuenta propia y salir adelante con el objetivo de brindar un mejor nivel de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Roberto Carlos is from El Sauce. He provides transportation services to residents of this town with a rickshaw; he has been in this line of work for 2 years. He has had three loans with Ceprodel that have been useful for him because he has been able to buy these assets to work independently and get ahead; the objective being to provide a better standard of living for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a rickshaw.

loans.name: Claribel Del Socorro

texts.es:
La Señora Claribel del Socorro B. G., tiene su negocio de venta de productos varios en el mercado ubicado de la iglesia el calvario 175 vrs al oeste, es madre soltera tuvo dos hijos ya son profesionales y ninguno depende de ella.
Ella abre su negocio de lunes a domingo de seis de la mañana a cinco y media de la tarde tiene dos trabajadores  que le ayudan a ver el negocio sus financiamientos los ocupa para invertirlo en su negocio siempre compra lo que este a la moda en las temporadas para aprovechar y vender mas,  desde  hace 33 años que tiene su negocio  lo empezo con un capital de C$5,000.00  que fueron aporte de sus hijos  ya que ella siempre deseo tener un negocio propio  lleva alrededor de cinco años de trabajar con ceprodel  y manifestó que con sus creditos  ha salido adelante y su negocio ha incrementado bastante
texts.en:
Mrs. Claribel del Socorro Blandon Garcia has her business selling various products in the market located 147 meters west of the El Calvario church. She is a single mother with two children who are professionals now. Neither depends on her. She opens her business Sunday through Monday from 6:00 in the morning until 5:00 in the afternoon. She has two workers who help her tend to the business. She uses her finances to invest in her business. She always buys what's in style for the season to make the most of it and sell more. She has had her business for 33 years. She started with C$5,000.00 of capital contributed by her children, since she always wanted to have her own business. She has been working with Ceprodel for around five years and she stated that with her loans she has been able to get ahead and her business has grown a lot.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in the business to purchase toys and children's clothes

loans.name: María Jesus

texts.es:
La señora  María Jesús  A. es socia del Banco Comunal  San Pablo, ella  vive en la comunidad Rumiloma que  se encuentra a unos diez minutos a las afueras de la ciudad de Cuenca, localidad que se dedica principalmente  a la agricultura y ganadería,  pero los jóvenes buscan en la ciudad nuevas y mejores oportunidades, nuestra socia se encuentra en 64 años de edad, es viuda hace 13 años porque su difunto esposo bebía en exceso, en su vida conyugal gestó  seis hijos quienes se encuentran de 42, 38, 36, 31, 27, 23 años,  sus cuatro hijos primeros  son casado y viven independientes con sus familias,  y sus dos hijos solteros viven con ella  pero no le ayudan con  los gastos del hogar, se siente muy orgullosa de haber construido su casa que aunque es pequeña es propia.

María Jesús  se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras,  desde su corta edad diez años empezó en ésta labor, trabaja cinco días a la semana  su horario de 8 a.m. hasta las 6 p.m. o según como termine la venta de su producto,  descansa los días martes y jueves.

Se encuentra en su cuarto ciclo en la fundación y los préstamos obtenidos ha invertido en  productos para abastecer su negocio, con el nuevo crédito  va a  comprar  manzanas, naranjas, naranjillas, uvas, acelga, zanahoria, remolacha, entre otras frutas y verduras para abastecer un poco su puesto para ofrecer a sus clientes   ya que éstos productos  se encuentran escasos  muy caros por la sequia que esta atravesando la región, su sueño es contar con buena salud para así seguir trabajando en su puesto de frutas y verduras que es su sustento diario.
texts.en:
María Jesús is a member of the San Pablo community banking group. She lives in the Rumiloma community, found 10 minutes outside of the city of Cuenca, whose primary business is that of farming and raising cattle - but the younger people look to the city for new and better opportunties. Our member is 64 years old, and has been widowed for 13 years. Her late husband drank in excess. She had 6 children who are 42, 38, 36, 31, 27, and 23 years old. Her first four children are married and live on their own with their families. Her two single children live with her, but don't help her with the household expenses. She feels very proud to have built her home, which although small, is her own. María Jesús works selling fruits and vegetables. From the young age of 10, she began this work, working 5 days a week from 8 am - 6 pm, or until she's sold out of her products. She has Tuesdays and Thursdays off. She is now in her 4th cycle with the foundation (ESPOIR) and the with loans she's received, she's invested in products to supply her business. With this new loan, she is going to buy apples, oranges, naranjillas (a citrus fruit from Ecuador), grapes, carrots, beets, among other fruits and vegetables, to supply her fruit stand to offer to her clients, since these scarce products are very expensive due to the the drought that has occurred in this region. Her dream is to remain in good health so that she can continue working in her fruit and vegetable stand which is her daily livelihood.

Translated from Spanish by Kimberly Baker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy apples, oranges, naranjillas, grapes, chard, carrots, beets, etc

loans.name: Phal's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Phal Hou is 39 years old and she is the village bank president of her group. She was selected by the members. The group consists of 12 people located in Stueng village in Kandal province. Each member of this group will use the loan to purchase supplies, equipment and other items for different purposes. Mrs. Phal Hou and her husband, Mr. Im Bin, are farmers who own a one-hectare field on which she grows crops. Although they try to work hard on her farming, they still don't earn enough income to support the family. Thus, Mrs. Phal Hou decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets for breeding. With this loan, she hopes to increase her income to improve her family's standard of living. This couple has five children; two are seamstresses in the garment factory, two are students in the local school and the youngest one is 5 years old.

loans.use: To buy piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Tunzale

texts.en: Born in 1974, Tunzale M. is married and has 4 children. Tunzale has been in this business for 10 years. Tunzale is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town, now settled in Absheron region. Now she needs a loan of 2,000 Azerbaijani Manat (AZN) to expand her shop.

loans.use: To expand her shop

loans.name: Janneth Margoth

texts.es:
Janneth Margoth T. G. tiene 52 años, es soltera, y vive con su mama de 85 años de edad. 
Ellas viven en el cantón de Chillanes en la provincia de Bolívar.
Janneth es un miembro de la ventanilla rural Santa Rosa de Agua Clara, que está ubicada a una distancia de 2 horas del Cantón  Chillanes.  Son 15 socios en total, los cuales la mayoría tienen pequeños negocios.
Janneth tiene un negocio de cabinas telefónicas  y bazar.  Ella compra sus productos en Guayaquil y en Bucay y vende en Santa Rosa de Agua Clara.
Janneth solicita el crédito para incrementar su negocio.  Su meta es agrandar el negocio o tener una microempresa.  Los desafíos que ella enfrenta en el negocio es la competencia y el desafío en su familia es la salud.
Por lo tanto, su familia es bien católica y unida.
texts.en:
Janneth Margoth T. G. is 52 years old, single, and lives with her 85-year-old mother. They live in Chillanes canton in the province of Bolívar. Janneth is a member of the Santa Rosa de Agua Clara rural loan group, which is located 2 hours away from Chillanes canton. There are 15 members of the group, and most of them have small businesses. Janneth’s business consists of a small general store with phone booths. She purchases her products in Guayaquil and Bucay and then sells them in Santa Rosa de Agua Clara. Janneth is asking for a loan so that she can increase her business. Her goal is to enlarge her business or to have a small company. The biggest challenge she faces in her business is competition, while the biggest challenge in her family right now is health issues. Therefore, her family is devoutly Catholic and very close.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing her business at her small general store

loans.name: Nguon

texts.en: Mr. Nguon P.,59, is a villager who lives in Prey Chheu Teal village, Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Sokhom Nhoeng, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living. Mr. Nguon P. decided to ask for a loan to buy two oxen to support his farm. Beside from farming, Mr. Nguon P. also works as a farm laborer to add to the family income. This couple has four children; three are seamstresses in the garment factory while the last one is a student. His wife is in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy two oxen for his farm

loans.name: Doloth

texts.en:
A. Doloth is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyotera in the Masaka area of Uganda. She is married and has one child. Doloth has a business running a retail shop in Kyotera. Doloth has had this business for about one year. 

To expand her business, Doloth is requesting a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more inventory to sell at her retail shop. Doloth hopes to expand her business, generating greater profit to use for her family.  


Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access financing at a young age and to improve their prospects for the future. The loans target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, to give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs, and to support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: Buy inventory for retail shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy seeds for farming business.

loans.name: Wilson Roberto

texts.es:
Wilson Roberto Y. D., tiene 34 años.  Es soltero y vive con los padres y un  hijo,  vive en Ventanas provincia de Los Ríos. Tiene 1 hijo,  Yesenia. 

Wilson es un socio de la ventanilla rural la “Y”, que está ubicada a hora y media de Ventanas. Son 17 socios en total, que en la mayoridad se dedican a la agricultura. Esto es el primer préstamo que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa San José.

Wilson  se dedica a transportar a la gente de la comunidad trabaja ya por 5 años. Realiza los fletes todos los días en la comunidad.

Solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de otra unidad de transporte. Piensa que el crédito es una oportunidad para salir adelante. Sus sueños es tener ingresos mayores para comprar una casa. Enfrenta desafíos es la falta de dinero y los caminos estan dañados.

Le gusta hacer deporte.
texts.en:
Wilson Roberto Y. D. is 34. He's single and lives with his parents and a child (Yessenia) in Ventanas in the province of Los Rios. Wilson is a member of the "Y" rural community bank that is about and hour and a half from Ventanas. There are a total of 17 members most of whom work in agriculture. This is their first loan with Cooperativa San Jose. Wilson has made a living transporting people in the community every day for the past 5 years. He is requesting a loan to purchase another transport vehicle. He feel the loan is an opportunity to get ahead. His dream is to have a better income to be able to buy a house. He faces challenges such as a lack of money and roads in poor conditions. He likes to play sports.

Translated from Spanish by Solson Scherman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase another transport vehicle

loans.name: Mirihan Liceht

texts.es:
MIRIHAN LICEHT A. M.,Trabaja Maestra B en la Universidad Nacional Autónoma de Nicaragua.
 Va a utilizarlo en su mejora de su casa de habitación y algunos gastos personales.Toda la plata que va trabajar  con Ceprodel  la ha utilizado en el mejoramiento de su casa de habitación, y solventar algunos gastos familiares.
 es madre soltera de un niño y este se encuentra en edad escolar.
texts.en:
Mirihan Liceht A. Martínez is working on her Master’s degree at the National Autonomous University of Nicaragua. She is going to use the loan to make improvements to her home and for some personal expenses. She has used her previous loans with Kiva partner CEPRODEL to improve her home and to settle some family expenses. She is a single mother who has one school-aged son.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Making home improvements such as remodeling the floor of her home, and settling some personal expenses.

loans.name: Mariela

texts.es: El Señora Mariela dedicada a la venta de ropa un ingreso que le da muchas satisfacciones ya que gracias a las ganancias obtenidas sus hijos pueden estudiar y sentirse orgullosos de su madre que desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana  ella sale a su venta , la señora necesita el crédito para aumentar su mercadería y comprar ropa de temporada ya que  muy pronto empezara la época de calor y desea comprar soleras y ropa delgada así ampliar sus opciones de venta, esta muy agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Mariela has a business selling clothing. This provides her with an income and with a lot of satisfaction, because thanks to the earnings she gets her children are able to study and feel proud of their mother, who leaves very early in the morning to make her sales. She needs a loan to increase her merchandise and to buy seasonal clothing, since very soon the summer season will begin. She wants to buy sundresses and thin clothing to expand her selling options. She is very grateful to the institution for providing this support.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy summer clothing
